DataElement.preferredName: Chronic Elevated Virus Timepoint PostBMT Response Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Identification of the status of chronic elevation of virus post bone marrow transplantation.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Chronic Elevated Virus Timepoint Post Transplantation Disease Response
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Minute infectious agents whose genomes are composed of DNA or RNA, but not both. They are characterized by a lack of independent metabolism and the inability to replicate outside living host cells._A specific point in the time continuum, including those established relative to an event._Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order._Transference of a tissue or organ within an individual, between individuals of the same species, or between individuals of different species._The pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment. The changes may include eradication of detectable disease, stabilization of disease, or disease progression._Usually used to describe a condition that is persistent and long standing._Raised or increased above normal levels or limits.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Usually used to describe a condition that is persistent and long standing.:Raised or increased above normal levels or limits.:Minute infectious agents whose genomes are composed of DNA or RNA, but not both. They are characterized by a lack of independent metabolism and the inability to replicate outside living host cells.

Concepts.definition: Usually used to describe a condition that is persistent and long standing.
Raised or increased above normal levels or limits.

An infectious agent which consists of two parts, genetic material and a protein coat. These organisms lack independent metabolism, and they must infect the cells of other types of organisms to reproduce. Most viruses are capable of passing through fine filters that retain bacteria, and are not visible through a light microscope.

Property.preferredDefinition: A specific point in the time continuum, including those established relative to an event.:Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.:Transference of a tissue or organ within an individual, between individuals of the same species, or between individuals of different species.:The pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment. The changes may include eradication of detectable disease, stabilization of disease, or disease progression.

Concepts.definition: A specific point in the time continuum, including those established relative to an event.
Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.
Transference of a tissue or organ within an individual, between individuals of the same species, or between individuals of different species.
The pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment. The changes may include eradication of detectable disease, stabilization of disease, or disease progression.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the response criteria (includes RECIST and others) and associated documentation of disease.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Curated to support NCI CCR Primary Immunosuppression CRF template.10.21.2016.dmr

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Exerting influence or producing an effect; taking part in an activity.: Minute infectious agents whose genomes are composed of DNA or RNA, but not both. They are characterized by a lack of independent metabolism and the inability to replicate outside living host cells.

Concepts.definition: Exerting influence or producing an effect.

An infectious agent which consists of two parts, genetic material and a protein coat. These organisms lack independent metabolism, and they must infect the cells of other types of organisms to reproduce. Most viruses are capable of passing through fine filters that retain bacteria, and are not visible through a light microscope.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Opportunistic Infection Completely Resolved with Further Intervention

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Opportunistic Infection Completely Resolved with Further Intervention
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Return to the normal structure and/or function, e.g. the subsidence of a pathologic process, as the subsidence of an inflammatory lesion or new growth.: Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.: An activity that produces an effect, or that is intended to alter the course of a disease in a patient or population. This is a general term that encompasses the medical, social, behavioral, and environmental acts that can have preventive, therapeutic, or palliative effects.: An infection caused by an organism which becomes pathogenic under certain conditions, e.g., during immunosuppression.

Concepts.definition: Return to the normal structure and/or function, e.g. the subsidence of a pathologic process, as the subsidence of an inflammatory lesion or new growth.
Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.

An activity that produces an effect, or that is intended to alter the course of a disease in a patient or population. This is a general term that encompasses the medical, social, behavioral, and environmental acts that can have preventive, therapeutic, or palliative effects.
Infection caused by an organism that is capable of causing disease in immunocompromised patients only (e.g. HIV-positive or transplanted patients).--2004
